maml:description.maml:para: Formats a virtual disk volume with a file system.

The Format-Volume cmdlet creates a new file system on a virtual disk volume (a disk volume is typically a disk partition).
After a volume is formatted, it can be used to store files.
An instance of DiscUtils.VolumeInfo, which describes the volume to format. If this parameter is specified, the Path parameter is ignored.
Path to the volume to be formatted. The parameter is ignored if InputObject is also supplied.
The file system to format the volume with, must be 'Ntfs'.
The display label for the formatted volume.
An instance of DiscUtils.VolumeInfo, which describes the volume to format. If this parameter is specified, the Path parameter is ignored.
Path to the volume to be formatted. The parameter is ignored if InputObject is also supplied.
The file system to format the volume with, must be 'Ntfs'.
The display label for the formatted volume.
Information about a volume to format.

maml:alert.maml:para: Note: The virtual disk must be opened for write access (see the -ReadWrite parameter on New-PSDrive).

dev:remarks.maml:para: Formats the first volume of a virtual disk with the NTFS file system. The volume is given the label 'My Files'.

maml:description.maml:para: Initializes a virtual disk by creating a partition table and assigning a serial number.

Initializing a virtual disk erases any existing partition structure, so should be done with caution.
Two kinds of partition structure are supported currently - BIOS (also known as MBR) and GPT.
Path to the virtual disk to be initialized. The parameter is ignored if InputObject is also supplied.
An instance of DiscUtils.VirtualDisk, which is the disk to be initialized. If this parameter is specified, the Path parameter is ignored.

The type of partition table to create - either Bios or Gpt.
Bios partition tables are widely recognized and are supported by the widest range of Operating Systems, but is limited in the size of disk that can be supported - but at 2TB is unlikely to be a limiting factor for virtual disk images in practice.
Gpt is a newer type of partition table, supported by modern Operating Systems that supports much larger disks, and also uses GUIDs (rather than a single byte) to differentiate the purpose of different partitions.
Creation of LDM partitions is not supported.
The unique identifier for this virtual disk.
Path to the virtual disk to be initialized. The parameter is ignored if InputObject is also supplied.
An instance of DiscUtils.VirtualDisk, which is the disk to be initialized. If this parameter is specified, the Path parameter is ignored.

The type of partition table to create - either Bios or Gpt.
Bios partition tables are widely recognized and are supported by the widest range of Operating Systems, but is limited in the size of disk that can be supported - but at 2TB is unlikely to be a limiting factor for virtual disk images in practice.
Gpt is a newer type of partition table, supported by modern Operating Systems that supports much larger disks, and also uses GUIDs (rather than a single byte) to differentiate the purpose of different partitions.
Creation of LDM partitions is not supported.
The unique identifier for this virtual disk.
The disk to initialize.
The initialized virtual disk.

maml:alert.maml:para: Note: The virtual disk must be opened for write access (see the -ReadWrite parameter on New-PSDrive).

dev:remarks.maml:para: Initializes a virtual disk with a BIOS (aka MBR) partition table, and the unique identifier 0x12345678.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new virtual disk.

The New-VirtualDisk cmdlet creates new virtual disk images. You can specify the type of disk image to create (VHD, VMDK, etc) and the variant.
This cmdlet does not initialize the contents of the disk, or create a file system on the disk.
This mandatory parameter specifies the name of the file to create.

Specifies the type of disk to create, which are described below:
VHD-fixed --------- Creates a new fixed-size VHD file. This kind of disk performs better than a dynamic VHD, but at the cost of taking a long time to create, and fully occupying the maximum size of the disk.
VHD-dynamic ----------- Creates a new dynamically-sized VHD file. This kind of disk initially occupies very little space, but as it's used, it will grow.
VMDK-fixed ---------- Creates a new fixed-size VMDK file. The file is a 'Hosted' style disk (i.e. this is the kind of disk used by VMware Workstation, VMware Server, etc). Disks of this kind are not fully interoperable with VMware ESX.
This kind of disk is known in the VMDK file format as "monolithicFlat".
VMDK-dynamic ------------ Creates a new dynamically-sized file. The file is a 'Hosted' style disk (i.e. this is the kind of disk used by VMware Workstation, VMware Server, etc). Disks of this kind are not fully interoperable with VMware ESX.
Unlike the other VMDK disk types, which occupy multiple files, this kind of disk resides in a single file.
This kind of disk is known in the VMDK file format as "monolithicSparse".
VMDK-vmfsfixed -------------- Creates a new fixed-size VMDK file. The file is an ESX style disk, and is interoperable with VMware workstation.
This kind of disk is known in the VMDK file format as "vmfs". Although called "vmfs", this is the kind of disk stored by ESX on NFS storage.
VMDK-vmfsdynamic ---------------- Creates a new dynamically-sized VMDK file. The file is an ESX style disk, and is interoperable with VMware workstation.
This kind of disk is known in the VMDK file format as "vmfsSparse".
VDI-fixed --------- Creates a new fixed size Virtual Box VDI file.
VDI-dynamic ----------- Creates a new dynamically sized Virtual Box VDI file.
RAW --- Creates a new RAW disk image file. These files are always the exact size of the disk created (equivalent to the 'fixed' variants of other disk formats). Typically these files are created by copying the raw bytes from an existing disk or partition.
A common use for raw disk images are virtual floppy disks, which are a typically a raw disk image directly containing a FAT file system.

The size of the disk image to create. This is the limit on the amount of data that can be stored in the disk. The size can be specified in bytes (B), kilobytes (KB), megabytes (MB) or gigabytes (GB) using the appropriate suffix.
If a dynamic disk variant is created, the actual amount of storage consumed will be less than the size of the disk. As the disk is filled, it will consume more storage space.
This mandatory parameter specifies the name of the file to create.
Creates a new differencing disk for an existing virtual disk. The BaseDisk parameter must also be specified, indicating the location of the existing disk.
When creating a differencing disk, this parameter specifies the location of the pre-existing base disk.
This mandatory parameter specifies the name of the file to create.

Specifies the type of disk to create, which are described below:
VHD-fixed --------- Creates a new fixed-size VHD file. This kind of disk performs better than a dynamic VHD, but at the cost of taking a long time to create, and fully occupying the maximum size of the disk.
VHD-dynamic ----------- Creates a new dynamically-sized VHD file. This kind of disk initially occupies very little space, but as it's used, it will grow.
VMDK-fixed ---------- Creates a new fixed-size VMDK file. The file is a 'Hosted' style disk (i.e. this is the kind of disk used by VMware Workstation, VMware Server, etc). Disks of this kind are not fully interoperable with VMware ESX.
This kind of disk is known in the VMDK file format as "monolithicFlat".
VMDK-dynamic ------------ Creates a new dynamically-sized file. The file is a 'Hosted' style disk (i.e. this is the kind of disk used by VMware Workstation, VMware Server, etc). Disks of this kind are not fully interoperable with VMware ESX.
Unlike the other VMDK disk types, which occupy multiple files, this kind of disk resides in a single file.
This kind of disk is known in the VMDK file format as "monolithicSparse".
VMDK-vmfsfixed -------------- Creates a new fixed-size VMDK file. The file is an ESX style disk, and is interoperable with VMware workstation.
This kind of disk is known in the VMDK file format as "vmfs". Although called "vmfs", this is the kind of disk stored by ESX on NFS storage.
VMDK-vmfsdynamic ---------------- Creates a new dynamically-sized VMDK file. The file is an ESX style disk, and is interoperable with VMware workstation.
This kind of disk is known in the VMDK file format as "vmfsSparse".
VDI-fixed --------- Creates a new fixed size Virtual Box VDI file.
VDI-dynamic ----------- Creates a new dynamically sized Virtual Box VDI file.
RAW --- Creates a new RAW disk image file. These files are always the exact size of the disk created (equivalent to the 'fixed' variants of other disk formats). Typically these files are created by copying the raw bytes from an existing disk or partition.
A common use for raw disk images are virtual floppy disks, which are a typically a raw disk image directly containing a FAT file system.

The size of the disk image to create. This is the limit on the amount of data that can be stored in the disk. The size can be specified in bytes (B), kilobytes (KB), megabytes (MB) or gigabytes (GB) using the appropriate suffix.
If a dynamic disk variant is created, the actual amount of storage consumed will be less than the size of the disk. As the disk is filled, it will consume more storage space.
Creates a new differencing disk for an existing virtual disk. The BaseDisk parameter must also be specified, indicating the location of the existing disk.
When creating a differencing disk, this parameter specifies the location of the pre-existing base disk.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates a 300GB dynamic VHD file, called newdisk.vhd
This example creates a new VMDK differencing disk (newdisk.vmdk) in the same folder as the base disk.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new registry hive.

The New-VirtualRegistry cmdlet creates new Windows registry hives.
To inspect and modify registry hives, create PowerShell drives using the 'virtualregistry' provider.
This mandatory parameter specifies the path of the registry hive to create.
This mandatory parameter specifies the path of the registry hive to create.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates a new registry hive called C:\temp\registry.hiv

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new volume (aka partition) on a virtual disk.
By default this cmdlet attempts to create a new partition that occupies the entire disk. Use the Size parameter to create a smaller partition.
An instance of DiscUtils.VirtualDisk, which is the disk to create the partition on. If this parameter is specified, the Path parameter is ignored.
Path to the virtual disk to be initialized. The parameter is ignored if InputObject is also supplied.

Specifies the size of the partition to create. The size can be specified in bytes (B), kilobytes (KB), megabytes (MB) or gigabytes (GB) using the appropriate suffix.
Note the actual partition created may not be the precise size requested, due to alignment rules.
The type of partition to create, one of WindowsFat, WindowsNtfs, Linux, LinuxSwap or LinuxLvm. Other types of partition are not supported.
Marks the volume as active, indicating the volume contains a bootloader.
An instance of DiscUtils.VirtualDisk, which is the disk to create the partition on. If this parameter is specified, the Path parameter is ignored.
Path to the virtual disk to be initialized. The parameter is ignored if InputObject is also supplied.

Specifies the size of the partition to create. The size can be specified in bytes (B), kilobytes (KB), megabytes (MB) or gigabytes (GB) using the appropriate suffix.
Note the actual partition created may not be the precise size requested, due to alignment rules.
The type of partition to create, one of WindowsFat, WindowsNtfs, Linux, LinuxSwap or LinuxLvm. Other types of partition are not supported.
Marks the volume as active, indicating the volume contains a bootloader.
The disk on which to create the new volume.
Information about the newly created volume.

maml:alert.maml:para: Note: The virtual disk must be opened for write access (see the -ReadWrite parameter on New-PSDrive).

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new 10MB NTFS volume on the virtual disk associated with PowerShell drive 'vdisk', marking the partition as active.
